Literature Review: Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) represents a significant public health issue, with profound implications for child development. Research has consistently demonstrated that children exposed to IPV are at a heightened risk for a range of adverse outcomes, including mental health problems, social difficulties, and academic underachievement (Holt, Buckley, & Whelan, 2008). The mechanisms through which IPV affects child development are complex and multifaceted, involving direct and indirect pathways that influence children's adjustment and well-being. One critical factor that has emerged in the literature is the role of child self-regulation in mediating the effects of IPV on developmental outcomes (Davies & Cummings, 1994). Self-regulation encompasses a child's ability to manage emotions, behaviors, and attention in response to environmental demands, and disruptions in this capacity can have far-reaching consequences for mental health and social functioning. Another significant aspect of the IPV-child development nexus is the impact of prenatal exposure to violence. Prenatal stress, including exposure to IPV, has been linked to alterations in fetal development, with potential long-term effects on child behavior and emotional regulation (Monk, Spicer, & Champagne, 2012). These findings underscore the importance of considering the timing of IPV exposure in understanding its developmental consequences. Methodological challenges in the field of IPV research include the predominance of variable-oriented and cross-sectional approaches, which limit the ability to capture the dynamic and transactional nature of the relationships between IPV exposure and child outcomes (Cummings, Davies, & Campbell, 2000). To address these limitations, researchers have called for the adoption of person-oriented and longitudinal designs that can provide a more nuanced understanding of the developmental trajectories of children exposed to IPV. A comprehensive theoretical model of the effects of IPV on children's development has been proposed, highlighting three mechanistic pathways: maternal representations, maternal mental health, and physiological functioning (Levendosky, Leahy, Bogat, Davidson, & von Eye, 2006). Maternal representations refer to the internalized images and beliefs that mothers hold about themselves and their relationships, which can be significantly affected by IPV and, in turn, influence parenting behaviors and child outcomes. Maternal mental health, particularly symptoms of depression and anxiety, has been identified as a critical mediator of the relationship between IPV exposure and child adjustment problems (Bogat, DeJonghe, Levendosky, Davidson, & von Eye, 2006). Physiological functioning, including stress response systems, has also been implicated in the transmission of IPV effects from mother to child, with dysregulation in these systems contributing to increased vulnerability to mental health and behavioral problems (Hibel, Mercado, & Trumbell, 2012). The effects of these three pathways on child adjustment outcomes are mediated through parenting and child self-regulation, highlighting the importance of interventions that target these mechanisms to mitigate the adverse effects of IPV on child development. Future research directions include the need for studies that examine the cumulative and interactive effects of multiple risk factors, as well as the protective factors that can promote resilience in children exposed to IPV (Gewirtz & Edleson, 2007). Clinical implications of this research include the development of interventions that address the specific needs of children and families affected by IPV, with a focus on enhancing parenting skills, supporting maternal mental health, and fostering child self-regulation (Lieberman, Van Horn, & Ippen, 2005). In conclusion, the literature on the developmental consequences of IPV on children highlights the complex interplay of factors that contribute to risk and resilience in this population. By advancing our understanding of these processes, researchers and clinicians can develop more effective strategies for supporting the healthy development of children exposed to IPV.
